Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 08:22PM MissUniverse wrote: I went on a water ride/roller coaster in San Diego last month. I was bound and determined to get over my fear of roller coasters and didn't want to pass up the opportunity when I had it because of head issues. I've had a hard time "embracing the bald" but my friends, who luckily were the only ones in my boat, encouraged me to take off my baseball hat.  I did, kept it down by my feet, and I have to say, it was incredibly freeing.  Even got a picture of it.  I say, embrace the bald!!
Posts.Title: Here is a fluff question I hope you can help me with Fitztwins pinkpig

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 08:25AM MissUniverse wrote: Monimoni, ITA with your statements about the procedures.  After my MRI with all the noise and the discomfort of the IV, the hanging the breasts down through those holes etc. I was convinced that a man had developed that machine. There is no way that a woman would allow another woman to go through that. If women developed the MRI machine, the holes would be padded and we would be able to wear headphones that piped in relaxing music and still allowed the tech to talk to us when they needed to. Ok, off my soap box too!!
Posts.Title: What a day.... Genia Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 11:13PM - edited Jul 9, 2008 11:20PM by MissUniverse Sis in Florida, I totally agree too.  Diagnosis is awful, chemo not a picnic (I type as I just got home from my 2nd cycle of A/C), and the roller coaster of all the treatments and tests is the worst. I got through the loss of my breast pretty well, it wasn't my favorite one anyways.  But right now my hair is coming out in large handfuls every time I touch my scalp and I find myself crying and crying.  I didn't cry that much when I was told I had to have a mastectomy - I saw it as a means to an end to get the cancer out of me. A woman I work with helped me put it into perspective.  I actually went to work for training less than 1 week after my mastectomy and have continued to work part-time every since (about 5 weeks ago).  I was worried about how people were going to handle me coming in with a wig on on Monday or a scarf. (My friends are having a Brittney Mania party for me on Sunday and we're shaving my head) She said that even though people knew I have bc, because of the way that I have been handling it, people didn't know know that I am ill but that the wig and/or scarf will be real evidence to them.  So, when I look in the mirror right now, even more so than looking at my scar, there is no denying that I have bc. AND IT SUCKS!! - there I rarely get whiny but needed it tonight because the affects of the A/C are starting to kick in.  Yipee!!  Hope this helps. PS - Oh gosh Otter, I just saw your Uncle Fester picture and died.  Halloween is huge for my family, haunted house special effects, people get in costume etc.  We have already been planning for new things for this year and just this past weekend my dad and I were talking about who I was going to be this year (I am usually the Bride of Frankenstein) and I very nonchallantly told him, I'm going to be Uncle Fester, easiest costume I ever have to come up with, and very little make-up.  So, for the past couple of days he has been sending my Uncle Fester picture.  I'll have to post them here after Halloween this year.  Too, too funny!!
Posts.Title: What I hate MOST about being bald! HeatherBLocklear dhettish

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 06:20AM MissUniverse wrote: My eating and exercise habits have both changed dramatically with my dx - for the better.  My onco firmly believes in the studies that show having extra weight increases the possibility of reoccurence.  So, right off the bat he advocated a healthy diet and exercise.  So, I'm doing the 8 - 10 glasses of water each day, have drastically increased my fiber intake, fruits and veggies intake way up, and I'm trying to exercise at least 3 times a week whether working out in the gym at my office or walking with some girls in my office along trails , when of course I have the energy.  I acknowledge  that the 4-5 days right after chemo it is tougher to exercise but at least try to get in some yoga at home on those days.  The result, I've lost 30 pounds in 3.5 months.  I've still got about 50 pounds to go and am bound and determined to shed them.  Anything that I can do to decrease the possibility of reoccurence and that helps to get me healthier, sign me up.
Posts.Title: Healthy weight to lower risk alohamomof3 NancyD

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 12:00PM MissUniverse wrote: I got lucky in the onco department.  I love my onco and my bs but don't like my gp.  Unfortunately it has been hard to find a gp in my area who is accepting new patients so I am just glad that I don't have to go to her very often.  I interviewed and researched the 2 onco's that my bs referred me to.  I ended up with the onco who had a sick sense of humor like me.  The other, a woman, wanted to coddle me which I get enough of from my friends, co-workers and family.  The onco I decided on even gave me a reference of a patient of his that went through the same protocol (DD A/C and Taxol).  I called her and she was incredibly honest about him.  I also spoke with his nurses and I really like them all which helps because I probably see and talk to them more than him - they sit in the infusion room with the patients and answer our questions. My attitude was that I needed to deal with these people for a long time and so if they had great credentials and I liked them, then they were the ones for me.  I read once that one of the most important aspects for patients is that they have faith in the team that is treating them.  I have total faith that Dr. Bedpan (his nickname because he has the bedside manner of a bedpan) and his staff are totally on my side, have my best interests at heart and will give me the best treatment available out there.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 01:44AM MissUniverse wrote: 53. "Now that you only have one breast, does that mean that you are only going to date guys with one ball??" This was actually said to me by a co-worker.  My response was that I didn't think there was an e-harmony site for that.  I wanted to ask her if she was only going to date guys with no brains!!
Posts.Title: 100 things never to say to a woman who has had a mastectomy: iwannabefree jillyG

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2008 12:26AM MissUniverse wrote: I didn't see the special but I actually downloaded and keep The Last Lecture on my computer for a reality check when I am feeling sorry for myself.  I also saw the interview with Diane Sawyer and his wife on youtube.  What amazing, amazing people.  It really hit me when Diane asked Jai, his wife, if she was at peace with things, and her response was that she had no choice but to be at peace with things. That she couldn't change things so she had to find her peace, accept things, and make the best of their time left. Wow.  I've  tried to be a Tigger since dx but Eeore does rear his head occassionally.  I have to get his book.  My prayers to his family.
